summary: This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons communications and logs regarding Jeffrey Epstein's medical care and psychological observation at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York in July-August 2019. It includes a pharmacist's note about his medication, a staff attorney's inquiry, and detailed observation logs tracking his status, meals, and activities while on suicide watch or psychological observation. This document contains suicide watch observation logs for an inmate (likely Jeffrey Epstein) and a detailed timeline of events surrounding his death on August 10, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It also includes internal email correspondence from September 2019 discussing UK extradition concerns and an addendum report critiquing suicide prevention protocols. This document is part of a UK extradition request for Jabir Motiwala. It includes a formal request for further information from US authorities regarding prison conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, prompted by the suicide of Jeffrey Epstein. The request cites a report by Maureen Baird detailing failures in Epstein's supervision and systemic issues at MCC, such as understaffing, falsified logs, and poor sanitation. This document is an investigative article detailing the horrific conditions at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Manhattan, including filth, vermin, abuse, and inadequate medical care. It uses the death of Jeffrey Epstein as a focal point to highlight systemic failures and includes testimonies from former inmates, attorneys, and human rights experts. The article also references political calls for investigation and reform.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The incarcerated individual at the center of the medical and psychological observation logs. He is referenced by his registration number (73618-054) and is the subject of medication allegations and suicide watch protocols.

persons.name: PharmD, MS, BCACP CAPT, U.S. Public Health Service Chief Pharmacist
persons.context: A commissioned officer in the U.S. Public Health Service serving as Chief Pharmacist at MCC New York. They communicated about Epstein's active prescription for Vascepa and its availability.

persons.name: Supervisory Staff Attorney CLC
persons.context: A legal staff member at the Metropolitan Correctional Center who relayed allegations from Epstein's attorneys that he was not receiving his cholesterol or back pain medication, prompting a medical review.

persons.name: Associate Warden MCC New York
persons.context: Bureau of Prisons official at the Metropolitan Correctional Center who was the recipient or sender of an email forwarding psychological observation and suicide watch documentation regarding Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Reyes Efrain
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate who departed for court on the morning of August 9, 2019, as noted in the suicide timeline.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: The Warden who arrived at the institution at 7:30 am on August 10, 2019, following the incident with Epstein.

persons.name: Judge Berman
persons.context: The judge who was notified of Epstein's death at 10:00 am on August 10, 2019, and later provided with a press release.

persons.name: Maureen Baird
persons.context: Author of a report dated August 22, 2019, detailing the events leading to Epstein's suicide and systemic failures at MCC. Her report is submitted as evidence in the Motiwala extradition proceedings.

persons.name: Pedro Espada
persons.context: Former inmate who provided an affidavit describing inhumane conditions in the suicide watch area at MDC Brooklyn, cited in an addendum report.

persons.name: Jabir Motiwala
persons.context: Individual sought for extradition by the US on charges of conspiracy to commit money laundering, extortion, and drug importation. His extradition hearing is ongoing, and his reported high suicide risk makes the Epstein case relevant.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: High-profile pre-trial inmate who died by suicide at MCC on August 10, 2019. His death and the circumstances surrounding it (removal from suicide watch, lack of cellmate, staff negligence) are central to the document's inquiry into prison conditions.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Described MCC as having 'deeply concerning irregularities' and expressed being 'appalled and angry' over the failure to adequately secure Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Amirah Ajaz
persons.context: Solicitor at ABV Solicitors who requested Maureen Baird's report on Epstein's suicide for the Motiwala extradition defense.

persons.name: Aviva Stahl
persons.context: Journalist who has extensively reported on poor conditions at MCC, including overcrowding, understaffing, vermin, and lack of medical care. Her work is cited in the document.

persons.name: Bill de Blasio
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of his pledge to shutter Rikers Island due to horrendous conditions, contrasting with less attention paid to MCC.

persons.name: Melvin Rodriguez
persons.context: Described spending three weeks at MCC in 2016 after a gang raid arrest, detailing bug and rodent infestations and stating the feds have a high conviction rate because they 'mentally break you.'

persons.name: Ricardo Stewart
persons.context: Another young man indicted in the Bronx gang raid who described seeing large rats in the MCC, comparing them to roommates.

persons.name: Joshua Dratel
persons.context: Attorney who has represented clients at Guantanamo and MCC, stating that MCC's 10 South unit is worse in some regards and describing the prison as 'soul-negating.'

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney who has visited clients at MCC, described the institution as 'infested with rats and mold' and cited the Epstein death as a result of its 'laziness and cruelty.'

persons.name: Jeanne Thesharis
persons.context: Professor at Brooklyn College who has written about MCC conditions, comparing the facility to a 'gulag' in lower Manhattan.

persons.name: Andrew Laufer
persons.context: Attorney who has filed lawsuits challenging conditions at MCC, describing a case where a prisoner had a fingertip chopped off and received inadequate medical care.

persons.name: Eric Holder
persons.context: Mentioned as the recipient of a 2011 letter from Amnesty International expressing concern about conditions on MCC's 10 South unit.

persons.name: Juan Mendez
persons.context: Former UN Special Rapporteur who investigated conditions at 10 South and determined international human rights protections had been violated, though the BOP prevented him from speaking to inmates.

persons.name: Susan Kellman
persons.context: Attorney with 30 years of experience representing clients at MCC, who described current conditions as 'the worst that it's ever been' and detailed specific cases of client neglect, including one in the Special Housing Unit where Epstein died.

persons.name: Martin Gottesfeld
persons.context: Inmate incarcerated in the 10 South unit of MCC who wrote an article and letter detailing appalling conditions, including rodent infestations, malfunctioning heat, and leaks. He is suing the BOP.

persons.name: Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman
persons.context: High-profile inmate housed in the 10 South unit of MCC during his trial, mentioned as an example of the secrecy and extreme conditions of the SAMs unit.

persons.name: Nydia Velazquez
persons.context: Congresswoman who has demanded answers about medical care and abuses at MCC since 2018 and, in August 2019, called for a comprehensive investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death and the facility's management problems.

events.title: Vascepa prescription dispensed
events.description: Epstein's prescription for Vascepa (a cholesterol medication) was dispensed for a 30-day supply.

events.title: Attorney medication allegations
events.description: Epstein's attorneys alleged he was not receiving his prescribed cholesterol or back pain medication, prompting an internal inquiry from the Supervisory Staff Attorney.

events.title: Psychological observation period
events.description: Epstein was placed on psychological observation, as documented in an attached log (Epstein Psych Observation 7-8-10-2019.pdf).

events.title: Second psychological observation period
events.description: Epstein was placed on another period of psychological observation, as documented in an attached log (Epstein Psych Observation 7-24-30-2019.pdf).

events.title: Document forwarding
events.description: An email was sent forwarding psychological observation and suicide watch chronological logs regarding Jeffrey Epstein to the Associate Warden.

events.title: Epstein's Last Full Day
events.description: Epstein's cellmate departs for court; Epstein attends attorney conferences throughout the day and receives a social call in the evening where he is reported in good spirits.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Pronounced Dead
events.description: At 6:33 am, staff find Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR is initiated, EMS arrives, and he is transported to Beekman Hospital where he is pronounced dead at 7:36 am.

events.title: Official Notifications and Investigation Launch
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the FBI, OIG, AUSA, Judge Berman, and next of kin are notified. The institution is placed on modified operations, and investigations begin.

events.title: UK Extradition Concerns Email
events.description: An AUSA emails BOP staff regarding UK concerns about extradition following Epstein's suicide, asking for assurances or information on improved safety measures.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York at approximately 6:40 am and was later pronounced dead. His death was ruled a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Epstein's First Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his jail cell with injuries to his neck and was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was reportedly removed from suicide watch and returned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with a cellmate.

events.title: Epstein's Cellmate Moved
events.description: Epstein's cellmate was moved, leaving him alone in his SHU cell, contrary to protocol for someone recently on suicide watch.

events.title: Barr Press Conference and Staff Reassignments
events.description: AG Barr held a press conference, expressing anger at MCC's failures. The MCC warden was reassigned and two staff members from Epstein's unit were placed on administrative leave.

events.title: New BOP Leadership Appointed
events.description: AG Barr appointed a new Director and Deputy Director to the Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: Arrest of Jabir Motiwala
events.description: Jabir Motiwala was arrested in connection with the US extradition request.

events.title: Motiwala Extradition Hearing
events.description: The extradition hearing for Jabir Motiwala proceeded in the Westminster Magistrates' Court.

events.title: Arrest of Melvin Rodriguez
events.description: Melvin Rodriguez was arrested in the Bronx on federal drug charges as part of the largest gang raid in New York City history, leading to his detention at MCC.

events.title: Correctional Officer Convicted of Rape
events.description: A former correctional officer at MCC was sentenced to seven years for raping an inmate.

events.title: Rep. Velazquez Demands Answers on MCC
events.description: U.S. Representative Nydia Velazquez sent a letter to the Federal Bureau of Prisons demanding details on medical care and conditions at MCC.

events.title: Calls for Investigation into Epstein's Death
events.description: Rep. Nydia Velazquez and other officials called for a comprehensive investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death and the culture of mismanagement at MCC.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was an inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York under registration number 73618-054 in July-August 2019.
Epstein's defense attorneys alleged he was not receiving his prescribed medications (cholesterol and back pain), prompting an official internal inquiry.
Epstein was placed on psychological observation/suicide watch on at least two documented occasions in July 2019 (July 8-10 and July 24-30).
Detailed logs tracked his meals, liquid intake, showers, and activities while under observation, indicating heightened monitoring.
Internal BOP communications show coordination between medical, legal, and administrative staff regarding Epstein's care and status.
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the MCC New York SHU at approximately 6:33 am on August 10, 2019, and was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 am.
A detailed minute-by-minute timeline documents the response to Epstein's suicide, including notifications to the FBI, OIG, AUSA, Judge Berman, and Epstein's brother.

Internal emails from September 2019 reveal the UK raised concerns about extraditing a prisoner (Motiwala) to the US following Epstein's suicide, seeking assurances about safety or alternative placement.
An addendum report cites a prior affidavit describing horrific, unsanitary conditions in a suicide watch cell at MDC Brooklyn, suggesting systemic issues in BOP suicide prevention protocols.

The document includes partially legible suicide watch observation logs for an inmate (Reg # beginning with 763 or 736), consistent with Epstein's details, though many entries are handwritten and difficult to decipher.

Staff assigned to monitor Jeffrey Epstein are suspected of falsifying log entries to show 30-minute checks were conducted when they were not; surveillance video allegedly confirms the checks were missed.
One of the two staff members monitoring Epstein the night of his death was reportedly not a regular corrections officer but a warehouse employee who had volunteered for overtime.

The MCC was reportedly operating with less than 70% of needed correctional officers, leading to mandatory overtime and 60-70 hour work weeks, which is cited as a contributing factor to the monitoring failure.
The prison was severely overcrowded, designed for 474 inmates but housing 763 on the day of Epstein's death, with reported sanitation issues including vermin infestations.
Epstein was left alone in his SHU cell on August 9, 2019, after his cellmate was moved, contradicting protocol for an inmate recently removed from suicide watch.
The Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Manhattan houses pre-trial detainees in conditions described as filthy, rat-infested, and abusive, with inadequate medical care.
Jeffrey Epstein's death by apparent suicide at MCC is presented as emblematic of the facility's systemic failures and dangerous environment for all inmates.

The 10 South unit at MCC, a Special Administrative Measures (SAMs) unit for high-profile inmates like El Chapo, subjects prisoners to extreme solitary confinement conditions condemned by human rights organizations.
The article alleges that pre-trial detention at MCC, which can last years, is used coercively to pressure inmates into accepting plea deals or providing information to prosecutors.
At the time of Epstein's death, MCC's inmate population was 763, far exceeding its designed capacity of 474, exacerbating staffing and condition problems.
